title: Dysregulated miR-124 mediates impaired social memory behavior caused by paternal early social isolation
affiliations: Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Neurodegeneration, Nanjing Medical University, Nanjing 211166, China
Center for Global Health, Nanjing Medical University, Nanjing 211166, China

background: Early social isolation (SI) in parents can negatively impact offspring emotion and behavior, but the mechanisms are unclear.
hypotheses: Paternal early SI causes social memory deficits and anxiety-like behavior in offspring.
Dysregulation of miR-124 mediates the intergenerational effects of early SI stress.
Altered miR-124/Nr4a1/glucocorticoid receptor expression in mPFC oligodendrocytes impacts myelinogenesis and social behavior.
major_findings: Paternal early SI caused social memory deficits and anxiety-like behavior in F1 mice, exacerbated by 2-week SI in F1 progeny.
Paternal SI led to mPFC hypomyelination and synaptic alterations in F1 mice, worsened by F1 SI.
Elevated miR-124 in paternal sperm was epigenetically transmitted to offspring, altering miR-124/Nr4a1/glucocorticoid receptor expression in mPFC oligodendrocytes.
Downregulating miR-124 or overexpressing Nr4a1 in the mPFC improved social interaction and myelin formation in F1 mice.
null_findings: One-week SI in F1 mice did not significantly exacerbate social memory impairment or anxiety-like behavior caused by paternal SI.
One-week or two-week SI in F1 mice did not significantly affect short-term working memory or anxiety-like behavior in the open field test.
Inhibiting miR-124 did not improve synaptic integrity in the mPFC.
new_open_questions: What are the long-term effects of paternal early SI on multiple generations of offspring?
How do other epigenetic mechanisms contribute to the intergenerational transmission of SI effects?
What are the specific roles of other brain regions in mediating the effects of paternal SI on offspring behavior?
methods: Behavioral tests (three-chamber test, open-field test, elevated plus maze, Y-maze)
Primary cortical neuron and oligodendrocyte precursor cell cultures
